paragraphs.zh-tw: The theme of my talk today is, "Be an artist, right now." Most people, when this subject is brought up, get tense and resist it: "Art doesn't feed me, and right now I'm busy. I have to go to school, get a job, send my kids to lessons ... " You think, "I'm too busy. I don't have time for art." There are hundreds of reasons why we can't be artists right now.
paragraphs.en: 今天我的演講主題是 現在就當個藝術家吧 大多數人，在聽到這個話題時 總是很緊張很抗拒 「藝術不是我的菜，而且我現在很忙。 我得上學，找工作 送我的孩子去補習⋯」 你想著「我太忙了，我沒時間搞藝術。」 我們有數百種現在不能當藝術家的理由

paragraphs.zh-tw: Don't they just pop into your head? There are so many reasons why we can't be, indeed, we're not sure why we should be. We don't know why we should be artists, but we have many reasons why we can't be.
paragraphs.en: 你現在是不是已經想到了幾個了？ 我們有太多不能當藝術家的理由 當然，其實我們也不知道為什麼要當個藝術家 我們不知道為什麼應該當藝術家 但我們有很多不能當的理由

paragraphs.zh-tw: Why do people instantly resist the idea of associating themselves with art? Perhaps you think art is for the greatly gifted or for the thoroughly and professionally trained. And some of you may think you've strayed too far from art.
paragraphs.en: 為什麼人們總是立刻抗拒把自己與藝術相連的想法？ 或許你認為藝術是給那些大有天分的人 或那些受過完整專業訓練的人 有些人可能認為自己離藝術太遠了

paragraphs.zh-tw: Well you might have, but I don't think so. This is the theme of my talk today.
paragraphs.en: 你或許這麼想，但我並不這麼認為 這就是我今天演講的主題

paragraphs.zh-tw: We are all born artists. If you have kids, you know what I mean.
paragraphs.en: 我們生來就是藝術家 如果你有小孩，你就知道我的意思

paragraphs.zh-tw: Almost everything kids do is art. They draw with crayons on the wall.
paragraphs.en: 幾乎孩子做的每件事都是藝術 他們拿蠟筆在牆上塗鴉

paragraphs.zh-tw: They dance to Son Dam Bi's dance on TV, but you can't even call it Son Dam Bi's dance -- it becomes the kids' own dance. So they dance a strange dance and inflict their singing on everyone.
paragraphs.en: 他們隨著電視上的孫丹菲跳舞 但那真的稱不上是孫丹菲的舞蹈那是孩子自己的創作 所以他們跳著奇怪的舞唱著讓大家痛苦的歌

paragraphs.zh-tw: Perhaps their art is something only their parents can bear, and because they practice such art all day long, people honestly get a little tired around kids. Kids will sometimes perform monodramas -- playing house is indeed a monodrama or a play.
paragraphs.en: 或許只有他們的父母能忍受他們的藝術 且因為他們一整天都在練習這樣的藝術 說真的，大家對孩子會覺得有點煩 孩子有時候還會表演獨角戲 玩扮家家酒就是一種獨角戲或說是一場戲劇

paragraphs.zh-tw: And some kids, when they get a bit older, start to lie. Usually parents remember the very first time their kid lies.
paragraphs.en: 某些孩子在長大一點後 開始說謊 通常父母都記得他們孩子第一次說謊的時候

paragraphs.zh-tw: They're shocked. "Now you're showing your true colors," Mom says. She thinks, "Why does he take after his dad?" She questions him, "What kind of a person are you going to be?" But you shouldn't worry.
paragraphs.en: 他們很震驚 「現在你的本性露出來了！」媽媽說。她心想，「為什麼跟他老爸一個樣呢？」 她質問他，「你知道你會變成什麼樣嗎？」 但你不需要擔心

paragraphs.zh-tw: The moment kids start to lie is the moment storytelling begins. They are talking about things they didn't see.
paragraphs.en: 孩子開始說謊的剎那就是說故事的開始 他們在說他們沒看到的事

paragraphs.zh-tw: It's amazing. It's a wonderful moment. Parents should celebrate.
paragraphs.en: 這很奇妙。這是非常奇妙的時刻 父母應該慶祝

paragraphs.zh-tw: "Hurray! My boy finally started to lie!" All right! It calls for celebration. For example, a kid says, "Mom, guess what? I met an alien on my way home." Then a typical mom responds, "Stop that nonsense." Now, an ideal parent is someone who responds like this: "Really? An alien, huh? What did it look like? Did it say anything? Where did you meet it?" "Um, in front of the supermarket." When you have a conversation like this, the kid has to come up with the next thing to say to be responsible for what he started.
paragraphs.en: 「萬歲！我的兒子終於會說謊了！」 是吧！是該慶祝的 舉個例，一個小孩說，「媽，你猜怎樣，我今天回家時碰到一個外星人！」 然後普通媽媽的回答是「不要胡說八道！」 那麼，理想的爸媽是這樣回應的： 「真的嗎？外星人啊？長什麼樣子？他跟你說了什麼嗎？」 「你在哪裡看到的？」「嗯，在超市前。」 當你們像這樣對話 這個小孩就得為他起了頭的事情想想接下來該怎麼回答

paragraphs.zh-tw: Soon, a story develops. Of course this is an infantile story, but thinking up one sentence after the next is the same thing a professional writer like me does.
paragraphs.en: 很快地，一個故事就這麼展開了 當然，這是小兒講的幼稚故事 但是他們能一句接著一句說 這跟像我這樣的專業作家做的事是一樣的

paragraphs.zh-tw: In essence, they are not different. Roland Barthes once said of Flaubert's novels, "Flaubert did not write a novel.
paragraphs.en: 他們在本質上沒有不同 羅蘭·巴特有一次提到福樓拜的小說 「福樓拜並不是寫小說。

paragraphs.zh-tw: He merely connected one sentence after another. The eros between sentences, that is the essence of Flaubert's novel." That's right -- a novel, basically, is writing one sentence, then, without violating the scope of the first one, writing the next sentence.
paragraphs.en: 他只是把句子接起來。 字句間奇妙的愛，成就了福樓拜小說的本質。」 沒錯，小說基本上就是寫一句話 然後在不違反第一句的情境下 寫出下一句

paragraphs.zh-tw: And you continue to make connections. Take a look at this sentence: "One morning, as Gregor Samsa was waking up from anxious dreams, he discovered that in his bed he had been changed into a monstrous verminous bug." Yes, it's the first sentence of Franz Kafka's "The Metamorphosis." Writing such an unjustifiable sentence and continuing in order to justify it, Kafka's work became the masterpiece of contemporary literature.
paragraphs.en: 然後你繼續連接句子 看看這句話： 「一天早上，葛雷戈·桑姆薩從不安的睡夢中醒來，發現自己在床上變成了一隻大得嚇人的甲蟲。」 是的，這是卡夫卡《變形記》的第一句話 他寫下這句不合理的句子 還要繼續寫下去使其合理化 卡夫卡的作品成為現代文學的名作

paragraphs.zh-tw: Kafka did not show his work to his father. He was not on good terms with his father.
paragraphs.en: 卡夫卡沒有把作品拿給父親看 他與他父親的關係並不好

paragraphs.zh-tw: On his own, he wrote these sentences. Had he shown his father, "My boy has finally lost it," he would've thought.
paragraphs.en: 他自己寫下這些句子 如果他讓他父親看過，他可能會想，「我的孩子終於瘋了。」

paragraphs.zh-tw: And that's right. Art is about going a little nuts and justifying the next sentence, which is not much different from what a kid does. A kid who has just started to lie is taking the first step as a storyteller.
paragraphs.en: 沒錯！藝術就是有一點瘋狂 並且還要使下一個句子合理化 這與一個孩子做的事也沒太多差別 一個剛剛開始說謊的小孩 正邁出講故事的第一步

paragraphs.zh-tw: Kids do art. They don't get tired and they have fun doing it.
paragraphs.en: 孩子們會做藝術 他們不會累，他們樂在其中

paragraphs.zh-tw: I was in Jeju Island a few days ago. When kids are on the beach, most of them love playing in the water.
paragraphs.en: 幾天前我在濟州島 孩子在海邊時，大都喜歡玩水

paragraphs.zh-tw: But some of them spend a lot of time in the sand, making mountains and seas -- well, not seas, but different things -- people and dogs, etc. But parents tell them, "It will all be washed away by the waves." In other words, it's useless.
paragraphs.en: 但有一些孩子會花很長時間在海灘 用沙堆積出山川和大海——啊，堆不出大海 不過有很多不同的東西——人啊狗之類的 但父母對他們說 「這些會被海浪沖掉。」 換句話說，這些是沒用的

paragraphs.zh-tw: There's no need. But kids don't mind.
paragraphs.en: 沒有用處 但孩子不在乎

paragraphs.zh-tw: They have fun in the moment and they keep playing in the sand. Kids don't do it because someone told them to.
paragraphs.en: 他們在那時刻玩得很開心 而且他們還會繼續玩沙 孩子並不是因為有人要求而做

paragraphs.zh-tw: They aren't told by their boss or anyone, they just do it. When you were little, I bet you spent time enjoying the pleasure of primitive art.
paragraphs.en: 他們不是被老闆要求 或被任何人要求，他們就是玩 當你還小，我打賭，你一定花過時間享受過單純藝術的樂趣

paragraphs.zh-tw: When I ask my students to write about their happiest moment, many write about an early artistic experience they had as a kid. Learning to play piano for the first time and playing four hands with a friend, or performing a ridiculous skit with friends looking like idiots -- things like that.
paragraphs.en: 當我要求我的學生寫下他們最快樂的時刻 很多都會寫他們還是孩子時非常早期的藝術經驗 第一次學鋼琴的時候第一次與朋友四手聯彈 或與朋友表演一段可笑的小短劇使自己看來像蠢蛋，諸如此類

paragraphs.zh-tw: Or the moment you developed the first film you shot with an old camera. They talk about these kinds of experiences.
paragraphs.en: 或是你洗出用老相機拍的第一張相片的時刻 他們談到這樣的經驗

paragraphs.zh-tw: You must have had such a moment. In that moment, art makes you happy because it's not work.
paragraphs.en: 你一定也有這樣的時刻 在那片刻，藝術使你快樂 因為那不是工作

paragraphs.zh-tw: Work doesn't make you happy, does it? Mostly it's tough. The French writer Michel Tournier has a famous saying.
paragraphs.en: 工作不能使你快樂，對吧？大部分工作都很艱辛 法國作家米歇爾·圖尼埃曾說過一句名言

paragraphs.zh-tw: It's a bit mischievous, actually. "Work is against human nature. The proof is that it makes us tired." Right? Why would work tire us if it's in our nature? Playing doesn't tire us.
paragraphs.en: 其實是有點調皮 「工作違反人性，其證明是它讓我們疲倦。」 是吧？如果工作是我們的本性，為什麼會好累？ 玩不會讓我們累

paragraphs.zh-tw: We can play all night long. If we work overnight, we should be paid for overtime.
paragraphs.en: 我們可以徹夜地玩 如果我們熬夜加班，就應該得加班費

paragraphs.zh-tw: Why? Because it's tiring and we feel fatigue. But kids, usually they do art for fun. It's playing.
paragraphs.en: 為什麼？因為那好累，我們覺得疲憊 但是孩子們，通常他們做藝術只是好玩。那是玩耍

paragraphs.zh-tw: They don't draw to sell the work to a client or play the piano to earn money for the family. Of course, there were kids who had to.
paragraphs.en: 他們畫圖並不是為了賣作品給客人 或彈鋼琴賺錢養家 當然有些孩子是為了養家

paragraphs.zh-tw: You know this gentleman, right? He had to tour around Europe to support his family -- Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart -- but that was centuries ago, so we can make him an exception. Unfortunately, at some point our art -- such a joyful pastime -- ends.
paragraphs.en: 你們都認得這位紳士吧？ 他得巡迴歐洲以養家 沃夫岡·阿瑪迪斯·莫札特 但那是幾個世紀以前的事所以我們可以說他是例外 不幸的是，我們的藝術——多好玩的消遣——到了某個時期就結束了

paragraphs.zh-tw: Kids have to go to lessons, to school, do homework and of course they take piano or ballet lessons, but they aren't fun anymore. You're told to do it and there's competition. How can it be fun? If you're in elementary school and you still draw on the wall, you'll surely get in trouble with your mom.
paragraphs.en: 孩子得去上課，去學校，做功課 當然他們還要學鋼琴，學芭蕾 但這些不再好玩了 你被要求去做這些，而且還有競爭，這樣怎麼好玩？ 如果你上了小學還在牆上塗鴉 我保證你媽會找你麻煩

paragraphs.zh-tw: Besides, if you continue to act like an artist as you get older, you'll increasingly feel pressure -- people will question your actions and ask you to act properly. Here's my story: I was an eighth grader and I entered a drawing contest at school in Gyeongbokgung.
paragraphs.en: 還有 如果你長大了還繼續表現得像個藝術家 你會感到日益增加的壓力 大家會質問你的行為且要求你要表現合宜 這是我的故事：我當時初三，我參加了一個學校畫圖比賽，在景福宮舉行

paragraphs.zh-tw: I was trying my best, and my teacher came around and asked me, "What are you doing?" "I'm drawing diligently," I said. "Why are you using only black?" Indeed, I was eagerly coloring the sketchbook in black.
paragraphs.en: 我很盡力地畫，然後我的老師走過來 問我，「你在做什麼？」 「我在努力畫畫，」我說 「為什麼你只用黑色？」 的確，我很急切地把寫生簿塗黑

paragraphs.zh-tw: And I explained, "It's a dark night and a crow is perching on a branch." Then my teacher said, "Really? Well, Young-ha, you may not be good at drawing but you have a talent for storytelling." Or so I wished. "Now you'll get it, you rascal!" was the response.
paragraphs.en: 所以我解釋 「天色很黑，有隻烏鴉棲息在樹枝上。」 然後我的老師說 「是嗎？唉！英夏，你大概不擅長畫畫，但你有講故事的天份。」 我真希望是這樣的回答 「你死定了！你這混蛋！」才是老師的回答

paragraphs.zh-tw: "You'll get it!" he said. You were supposed to draw the palace, the Gyeonghoeru, etc., but I was coloring everything in black, so he dragged me out of the group.
paragraphs.en: 「你死定了你！」他說 你應該要畫這個宮殿，景福宮之類的 但是我把每樣東西都塗黑了 所以他把我踢了出去

paragraphs.zh-tw: There were a lot of girls there as well, so I was utterly mortified. None of my explanations or excuses were heard, and I really got it big time.
paragraphs.en: 當時那裡還有很多女孩子 我丟臉死了 我的解釋或理由都不被接受 而且我真的是死很大

paragraphs.zh-tw: If he was an ideal teacher, he would have responded like I said before, "Young-ha may not have a talent for drawing, but he has a gift for making up stories," and he would have encouraged me. But such a teacher is seldom found.
paragraphs.en: 如果他是位理想的老師他會以我之前說的來回應 「英夏或許在畫畫上沒有天份 但他在編故事上很有一手，」然後他還可以鼓勵我一下 但這樣的老師很難找到

paragraphs.zh-tw: Later, I grew up and went to Europe's galleries -- I was a university student -- and I thought this was really unfair. Look what I found.
paragraphs.en: 後來，我長大後去了趟歐洲的畫廊 那時我是大學生而我心想這實在是太不公平了 看我找到什麼！

paragraphs.zh-tw: Works like this were hung in Basel while I was punished and stood in front of the palace with my drawing in my mouth. Look at this. Doesn't it look just like wallpaper? Contemporary art, I later discovered, isn't explained by a lame story like mine.
paragraphs.en: 當我被懲罰的時候像這樣的作品就高掛在巴塞爾 而我在景福宮前罰站嘴裡塞着我的畫 看看這個！這難道不像壁紙嗎？ 當代藝術，我後來發現，不會像我

paragraphs.zh-tw: No crows are brought up. Most of the works have no title, Untitled.
paragraphs.en: 用一個憋腳的故事來解釋畫作不會提到烏鴉 大部分的作品是沒有標題的，《無題》

paragraphs.zh-tw: Anyways, contemporary art in the 20th century is about doing something weird and filling the void with explanation and interpretation -- essentially the same as I did. Of course, my work was very amateur, but let's turn to more famous examples.
paragraphs.en: 反正二十世紀的當代藝術 就是做一些怪怪的東西然後隨你解釋及詮釋 跟我那時做的本質一樣 當然，我的作品非常不成熟 但我們來看看一些更有名的例子

paragraphs.zh-tw: This is Picasso's. He stuck handlebars into a bike seat and called it "Bull's Head." Sounds convincing, right? Next, a urinal was placed on its side and called "Fountain".
paragraphs.en: 這是畢卡索的作品 他把自行車把手插進座墊裡然後稱之為《牛頭》，很有說服力吧？ 下一張，把小便池翻轉以側邊平放，然後稱它為《噴泉》

paragraphs.zh-tw: That was Duchamp. So filling the gap between explanation and a weird act with stories -- that's indeed what contemporary art is all about.
paragraphs.en: 那是杜象的作品 所以用故事來解釋怪怪的行為 那的確是當代藝術的重點所在

paragraphs.zh-tw: Picasso even made the statement, "I draw not what I see but what I think." Yes, it means I didn't have to draw Gyeonghoeru. I wish I knew what Picasso said back then. I could have argued better with my teacher.
paragraphs.en: 畢卡索甚至發表聲明 「我不畫我所看到的，我畫我所想的。」 是的，這就是說我不需要畫景福宮 我真希望當時我知道畢卡索說的這句話這樣我就可以跟老師好好辯論一番

paragraphs.zh-tw: Unfortunately, the little artists within us are choked to death before we get to fight against the oppressors of art. They get locked in.
paragraphs.en: 可惜，這在我們體內的小小藝術家 在我們與迫害藝術者爭鬥前就已經窒息而死了 他們被封閉住

paragraphs.zh-tw: That's our tragedy. So what happens when little artists get locked in, banished or even killed? Our artistic desire doesn't go away.
paragraphs.en: 那是我們的悲劇 所以當小藝術家被封閉、放逐或甚至殺了，會怎麼樣呢？ 我們對藝術的渴望不會消失

paragraphs.zh-tw: We want to express, to reveal ourselves, but with the artist dead, the artistic desire reveals itself in dark form. In karaoke bars, there are always people who sing "She's Gone" or "Hotel California," miming the guitar riffs.
paragraphs.en: 我們仍然想表達表現自我 但是隨著藝術家之死，這個渴望會用隱諱的形式表現出來 在卡拉OK店，總有人唱著 《她離開了我》或《加州旅館》 模仿彈吉他的樣子

paragraphs.zh-tw: Usually they sound awful. Awful indeed. Some people turn into rockers like this.
paragraphs.en: 通常這些人都唱得很爛真的很爛 有些人變成像這樣的搖滾迷

paragraphs.zh-tw: Or some people dance in clubs. People who would have enjoyed telling stories end up trolling on the Internet all night long.
paragraphs.en: 有些人在夜店裡跳舞 那些原本可以開心講故事的人 最後變成整晚掛網

paragraphs.zh-tw: That's how a writing talent reveals itself on the dark side. Sometimes we see dads get more excited than their kids playing with Legos or putting together plastic robots.
paragraphs.en: 那就是寫作天分的隱諱表現 有時候我們看見爸爸比小孩還激動 玩著樂高或組塑膠機器人

paragraphs.zh-tw: They go, "Don't touch it. Daddy will do it for you." The kid has already lost interest and is doing something else, but the dad alone builds castles. This shows the artistic impulses inside us are suppressed, not gone.
paragraphs.en: 他們會說，「不要碰。爸爸幫你做。」 小孩已經失去興趣，去玩別的東西了 爸爸還在那裡一個人組城堡 這顯示在我們體內，想當藝術家的衝動是被壓制了，並沒有消失

paragraphs.zh-tw: But they can often reveal themselves negatively, in the form of jealousy. You know the song "I would love to be on TV"? Why would we love it? TV is full of people who do what we wished to do, but never got to.
paragraphs.en: 但這股衝動也常常以負面的嫉妒形式表現 你們知道《我想上電視》這首歌吧?我們為什麼喜歡它呢? 因為電視里的人在做我們希望做 但無法達成的事

paragraphs.zh-tw: They dance, they act -- and the more they do, they are praised. So we start to envy them.
paragraphs.en: 他們跳舞、演戲——做得愈多得到的讚賞也愈多 所以我們開始嫉妒他們

paragraphs.zh-tw: We become dictators with a remote and start to criticize the people on TV. "He just can't act." "You call that singing? She can't hit the notes." We easily say these sorts of things.
paragraphs.en: 我們成為手拿遙控器的獨裁並且開始對電視上的那些人品頭論足 「他根本不會演！」「那個也叫唱歌？她根本五音不全。」 我們很容易說長道短這些東西

paragraphs.zh-tw: We get jealous, not because we're evil, but because we have little artists pent up inside us. That's what I think.
paragraphs.en: 我們嫉妒不是因為我們很壞 而是因為體內被壓抑的藝術家 至少我是這麼認為

paragraphs.zh-tw: What should we do then? Yes, that's right. Right now, we need to start our own art.
paragraphs.en: 那我們應該怎麼做？ 是的，沒錯 就在當下，我們要開始自己的藝術

paragraphs.zh-tw: Right this minute, we can turn off TV, log off the Internet, get up and start to do something. Where I teach students in drama school, there's a course called Dramatics.
paragraphs.en: 就在這一分鐘，我們可以關掉電視 從網路下線 站起來開始做些什麼 在我教學生的戲劇學校 有一門演技課

paragraphs.zh-tw: In this course, all students must put on a play. However, acting majors are not supposed to act.
paragraphs.en: 在這堂課裡學生一定要演戲 然而，主修表演的人不一定會演戲

paragraphs.zh-tw: They can write the play, for example, and the writers may work on stage art. Likewise, stage art majors may become actors, and in this way you put on a show.
paragraphs.en: 舉個例，他們也可以寫劇本 而劇作家也可能作舞台藝術 同樣的，主修舞台藝術的人也可能當演員，這樣你也能演出戲劇

paragraphs.zh-tw: Students at first wonder whether they can actually do it, but later they have so much fun. I rarely see anyone who is miserable doing a play. In school, the military or even in a mental institution, once you make people do it, they enjoy it.
paragraphs.en: 學生一開始都懷疑自己能不能做到 但後來他們都做得很開心，我幾乎不曾看過誰演戲的時候很悲慘 在學校、軍隊甚至在精神療養院一但你讓人們演戲，他們都很喜歡

paragraphs.zh-tw: I saw this happen in the army -- many people had fun doing plays. I have another experience: In my writing class, I give students a special assignment.
paragraphs.en: 我親眼看到這在軍中發生很多人在演戲時很開心 我還有另一個經驗 在我的寫作課我給學生一項很特別的作業

paragraphs.zh-tw: I have students like you in the class -- many who don't major in writing. Some major in art or music and think they can't write.
paragraphs.en: 我的班上有很多像你們一樣的學生主修不是寫作 有些人主修藝術、音樂他們都認為自己不能寫作

paragraphs.zh-tw: So I give them blank sheets of paper and a theme. It can be a simple theme: Write about the most unfortunate experience in your childhood.
paragraphs.en: 所以我給他們白紙及一個主題 可以是很簡單的主題 寫下你兒時最悲慘的經驗

paragraphs.zh-tw: There's one condition: You must write like crazy. Like crazy! I walk around and encourage them, "Come on, come on!" They have to write like crazy for an hour or two. They only get to think for the first five minutes.
paragraphs.en: 有一個條件：你必須像瘋了一樣的寫像瘋了一樣 我在教室走來走去鼓勵他們 「快寫！快寫！」他們必須像瘋子一樣寫一到二小時 他們只能在最初的五分鐘想一下

paragraphs.zh-tw: The reason I make them write like crazy is because when you write slowly and lots of thoughts cross your mind, the artistic devil creeps in. This devil will tell you hundreds of reasons why you can't write: "People will laugh at you. This is not good writing! What kind of sentence is this? Look at your handwriting!" It will say a lot of things.
paragraphs.en: 我之所以要讓他們像瘋了一樣的寫是因為 當你慢慢的寫，就會有很多事在你腦中跑來跑去 藝術惡魔會偷偷跑進來 這惡魔會告訴你千百個理由 為什麼你不會寫 「大家會笑你。這寫得不好。」 「你在寫什麼句子？看看你的筆跡！」 它會說很多事

paragraphs.zh-tw: You have to run fast so the devil can't catch up. The really good writing I've seen in my class was not from the assignments with a long deadline, but from the 40- to 60-minute crazy writing students did in front of me with a pencil.
paragraphs.en: 你一定要快跑以免被惡魔抓到 我在課堂上見過的佳作 不是給他們帶回家寫很久以後才要交的作業 而是在我面前，像瘋子一樣以一枝鉛筆 寫了40到60分鐘的故事

paragraphs.zh-tw: The students go into a kind of trance. After 30 or 40 minutes, they write without knowing what they're writing.
paragraphs.en: 學生都寫到有點恍神了 他們寫了30或40分鐘後都不知道自己還在寫

paragraphs.zh-tw: And in this moment, the nagging devil disappears. So I can say this: It's not the hundreds of reasons why one can't be an artist, but rather, the one reason one must be that makes us artists.
paragraphs.en: 而這個時刻，碎碎念的惡魔消失了 所以我可以這麼說： 並不是那千百個理由讓我們當不成藝術家 反而是那個我們想要的唯一理由使我們成為藝術家

paragraphs.zh-tw: Why we cannot be something is not important. Most artists became artists because of the one reason.
paragraphs.en: 為什麼做不了某件事並不重要 大部分的藝術家之所以能成為藝術家只有一個理由

paragraphs.zh-tw: When we put the devil in our heart to sleep and start our own art, enemies appear on the outside. Mostly, they have the faces of our parents.
paragraphs.en: 當我們把惡魔關在心裡睡覺開始做一些藝術 敵人就在外部出現 他們大半以父母的形象出現

paragraphs.zh-tw: Sometimes they look like our spouses, but they are not your parents or spouses. They are devils. Devils.
paragraphs.en: 有時候他們看起來像我們的配偶 但他們不是你的父母或配偶 他們是惡魔。惡魔。

paragraphs.zh-tw: They came to Earth briefly transformed to stop you from being artistic, from becoming artists. And they have a magic question.
paragraphs.en: 他們降到世間，很快地轉變形象 以阻止你當藝術家，或成為藝術家 而且他們還有一個屢試不爽的神奇問題

paragraphs.zh-tw: When we say, "I think I'll try acting. There's a drama school in the community center," or "I'd like to learn Italian songs," they ask, "Oh, yeah? A play? What for?" The magic question is, "What for?" But art is not for anything. Art is the ultimate goal.
paragraphs.en: 當我們說，「我想試試演戲。社區中心有個影劇學校，」或 「我想學唱歌劇，」他們就問「喔？是嗎？演戲？為了什麼？」 這神奇的問題就是：「為了什麼？」 但藝術並不是為了什麼 藝術是最終的目標

paragraphs.zh-tw: It saves our souls and makes us live happily. It helps us express ourselves and be happy without the help of alcohol or drugs.
paragraphs.en: 它拯救我們的靈魂，使我們活得快樂 它幫助我們表達自我使我們不需要酒精或藥物就能快樂

paragraphs.zh-tw: So in response to such a pragmatic question, we need to be bold. "Well, just for the fun of it. Sorry for having fun without you," is what you should say. "I'll just go ahead and do it anyway." The ideal future I imagine is where we all have multiple identities, at least one of which is an artist.
paragraphs.en: 所以要回答這麼現實的問題 我們必須大膽 「嗯，就好玩嗎！對不起喔，我沒找你一起玩！」 這就是你應該說的。「我要開始做囉！不管你了！」 我想像中的理想未來是我們擁有很多身份 而其中之一是藝術家

paragraphs.zh-tw: Once I was in New York and got in a cab. I took the backseat, and in front of me I saw something related to a play. So I asked the driver, "What is this?" He said it was his profile. "Then what are you?" I asked. "An actor," he said.
paragraphs.en: 有一次我在紐約搭計程車我坐在後座 我看到座前有個跟戲劇有關的東西 所以我問司機，「這是什麼？」 他說這是他的簡介。「那你是做什麼的？」我問。「演員，」他說。

paragraphs.zh-tw: He was a cabby and an actor. I asked, "What roles do you usually play?" He proudly said he played King Lear. King Lear.
paragraphs.en: 他是計程車司機兼演員。我又問：「你都演什麼角色？」 他很驕傲地說他演李爾王 李爾王！

paragraphs.zh-tw: "Who is it that can tell me who I am?" -- a great line from King Lear. That's the world I dream of.
paragraphs.en: 「誰能告訴我我是誰？」是李爾王的名言 那就是我夢想的世界

paragraphs.zh-tw: Someone is a golfer by day and writer by night. Or a cabby and an actor, a banker and a painter, secretly or publicly performing their own arts.
paragraphs.en: 某人白天是高爾夫球手，晚上當作家 或計程車司機兼演員；銀行家兼畫家 秘密或公開地表演他們的藝術

paragraphs.zh-tw: In 1990, Martha Graham, the legend of modern dance, came to Korea. The great artist, then in her 90s, arrived at Gimpo Airport and a reporter asked her a typical question: "What do you have to do to become a great dancer? Any advice for aspiring Korean dancers?" Now, she was the master. This photo was taken in 1948 and she was already a celebrated artist.
paragraphs.en: 1990年，瑪莎·葛蘭姆這位現代舞蹈傳奇人物到韓國訪問 這位已經90多歲的藝術家抵達金浦機場時 記者問了她一個典型的問題 「要怎麼做才能成為一位偉大的舞者？ 有沒有什麼忠告給有抱負的韓國舞者？」 她是大師。這張照片拍攝於1948年而她當時已經是位有名的藝術家

paragraphs.zh-tw: In 1990, she was asked this question. And here's what she answered: "Just do it." Wow. I was touched.
paragraphs.en: 1990年，記者問了她這個問題 而這是她的回答 「就去做！」 哇，我大受感動

paragraphs.zh-tw: Only those three words and she left the airport. That's it. So what should we do now? Let's be artists, right now. Right away. How? Just do it! Thank you.
paragraphs.en: 她只說了這三個字就離開了機場就這樣 所以我們現在應該怎麼做？ 來當藝術家吧！現在！就在當下！要怎麼做？ 就去做！ 謝謝

title: Young Ha Kim Be An Artist Right Now
